Understand the relative contribution and sensitivity of features in forming and separating clusters

A classification, via calculation utilizing mathematical precision to identify based on numeric similarity, attributes, characteristics, properties and behaviours across multidimensional space. Clustering has material advantages relative to more simplistic human derived techniques as it is not limited to ambigious thresholds or static rules (which can be time consuming, incorrect and subject to constant change).

Identify explicit groups of members which posses explicit tendancies, characteistics and patterns which the organiation understand and support through tailored strategies, plans and products.

When choosing, need to have a explicit understanding of how and why your choice is being made. Trade Offs include; 
Speed vs Accuracy
Accuracy vs Repeatability
Correlation vs Causation
Stability over Uniqueness
Interpretability over novelty
Repeatability over perfection.
Define the intended use, boundaries, and decision domains for archetype-based strategies
Ensure Data is Labelled and Categorized.
Review Semantic Classifications, insure sufficient and appropriate model coverage.
Characterize each archetype using clear, interpretable behavioural and financial characteristics
Design and apply differentiated engagement strategies aligned to each archetype’s characteristics and needs
Identify and validate the behavioural attributes, transactions, and usage patterns that define similarity among members
Identify and define distinct, stable member archetypes based on observed behavioural patterns
Monitor archetype-level outcomes, migration, and engagement effectiveness over time

Goals of a clustering project can greatly differ, as such there is no universal approach, and in fact the type of clustering which one undertakes differs greatly depending upon goals, objectives, expected outcomes and availabiltiy of data.

At the simplest, the type of Clustering (Supervised vs Unsupervised) is likely the first and easiest distinction, types after that depend on size of data, goals, implementation (real time vs batch), time frame (spot vs time series, member vs member, member vs self, etc).

Example of Behavior Goal: Small Number of Stable, Interpretable, Member Archetypes that summaize the global behavior and can be reused for ML and Analysis.

With clustering, the following strategic outcomes can be achieved: 
Strategic Conversations become diagnostic not reactive
Precision without Personalization
Differenitation without Discrimination
Optimization without cumbersome rules

Process of identifying and retaining the most relevant variables for model training while removing redundant, noisy, or irrelevant features. This helps reduce overfitting, improve model performance, and increase interpretability. Feature selection techniques may be statistical, model-based, or embedded within the learning algorithm. The goal is to create a simpler, more robust feature set that generalizes well to new data.

It is important to be in a position to Logically and Mathematically be in a position to defend inclusion and exclusion decisions. Although a highly technical step, it is critically important that stakeholders and partners are included and in references and terms which are appropriate for them.

Establish a clear, concise and explicit goal for the project. While ideally the goal will be defined in terms of Key Performance Indicators, when the work is truly explorative or borne in the spirt of true experiementation, it is still critical to establish guardrails, and get everyone to agree. Additional, there needs to be a deliverable, again even if vague, a deliverable needs to be agreed upon and structured in some format to insure that all parties have appropriately managed expectations.

There should be no more than 3 Goals (Flexible), the goals should be SMART and explicitly acknowledged and supported by the

A Clear, Concise and explicit definition of the problem at hand, or a "Problem Statement". A problem statement should be simple, and include at a minimum 5 items; a 1) current state analysis, 2) root cause assessment, 3) historical overview of what has been done, 4) metrics quantifying the current state (baseline), and 5) metrics quantifying (or providing insight into the desired state). 

Proceed with extreme caution where the problem statement is incomplete, or ill-stated, as this is likely indicative that the problem is not truly understood or at a minimum defined. Where this is the case, the project will be at extreme risk the likelihood of change to project purpose, scope or priority likely.

Data preparation focuses on cleaning and structuring raw data into a usable format for modeling. This includes handling missing values, correcting errors, standardizing formats, encoding categorical variables, and aligning labels with features. It also often involves train/validation/test splitting to prevent data leakage. This step is critical because most models assume clean, well-structured inputs and are highly sensitive to data issues.

Need to establish up a consistent, robust and repeatable data ingestion process, which starts at the outset of the project. Where the infrastructure is not immediately available, need to clearly document the journey.  Need to call out requirements, expectations and limitations, and where resources are necessary, they should be identified at this point. 

Where operational changes are necessary, or a prerequisite, need to understand how these will documented and escalated or addressed.

Process of explaining how a model makes predictions and which features influence its decisions. This may involve feature importance, partial dependence plots, SHAP values, or simpler surrogate models. Interpretability helps stakeholders understand, trust, and validate the model’s behavior. It is especially important in regulated or high-impact decision environments.

Data collection involves identifying, sourcing, and acquiring the datasets required to solve the defined problem. This may include internal databases, APIs, logs, third-party data, or manually collected data. Key considerations include data availability, coverage, granularity, freshness, and legal or privacy constraints. The quality and relevance of collected data fundamentally limit the ceiling of model performance.

Need to understand the data available to solve a problem, insure that it's documented, understood and trusted. Need to identify, not only information which is available, but information which is not available and should be.  This should be explicitly documented, referenced constantly and readily available (Semantic and Functional Definition).

The process of choosing the most appropriate algorithm or model type for a given problem and dataset. This decision is based on factors such as data size, feature structure, interpretability needs, computational constraints, and performance requirements. Multiple candidate models are often tested and compared using consistent evaluation methods. The objective is to identify the model that provides the best balance between accuracy, stability, and practical usability.

Similiar to the process of engagement and audit followed in Feature Selection, it is critically important that actions are documented, defensable and clearly and consistently articulated to stakeholders in a meaningful manner.

Ongoing process of tracking model performance and data quality after deployment. It helps detect issues such as data drift, concept drift, performance degradation, or system failures. Monitoring ensures the model continues to perform as expected over time. When problems are detected, retraining or model updates may be required.

Foundational step in ensuring the success of a machine learning model—and, by extension, the overall project. Its purpose is to confirm that the data is appropriately structured, consistent, and of sufficient quality to support reliable modeling.

While every dataset and project is unique, applying a consistent EDA approach helps reduce the laborious and time-consuming nature of data preparation. A structured process enables quicker identification of data issues, improves understanding of key variables and relationships, and creates a more stable foundation for subsequent modeling decisions.

Process of creating new input variables that better represent the underlying patterns in the data. It may include transformations (log, scaling), aggregations, interactions, temporal features, or domain-specific encodings. Effective feature engineering can significantly improve model performance even with simple algorithms. It embeds domain knowledge into the model and often provides more value than algorithmic complexity.  It is often one of the most impactful steps in the machine learning workflow.

Process of fitting a machine learning model to data so it can learn the relationships between input features and the target variable. During training, the model adjusts its internal parameters to minimize a loss function. This step typically occurs on a designated training dataset. The quality of training directly affects the model’s ability to generalize to new, unseen data.

Optimizing the configuration settings that control how a model learns, rather than the parameters learned during training. These settings, such as tree depth or regularization strength, can significantly influence model performance and stability. Tuning is typically done using methods like grid search, random search, or Bayesian optimization. The goal is to identify the hyperparameter combination that produces the best validation performance.

Process of measuring how well a trained model performs using appropriate metrics and test data. This step assesses predictive accuracy, generalization, and robustness. Different metrics are used depending on the problem type, such as accuracy, F1 score, RMSE, or AUC. Evaluation ensures the model meets performance expectations before deployment, and results often determine whether a model is production-ready.

Validation is the process of assessing model performance on data that was not used during training. It is used to tune hyperparameters, compare models, and detect overfitting. Common approaches include hold-out validation and cross-validation techniques. The purpose is to estimate how well the model will perform on unseen data.

Deployment is the process of integrating the trained model into a production environment where it can generate real-world predictions. This may involve APIs, batch pipelines, streaming systems, or embedded applications. Considerations include scalability, latency, reliability, and versioning. Deployment turns a model from an experiment into a usable product. The goal is to make the model usable and operational in real-world settings.

This step examines whether the model produces systematically unfair or harmful outcomes across different groups. It includes analyzing data representation, outcome disparities, and unintended correlations. Ethical considerations may involve transparency, consent, explainability, and regulatory compliance. Addressing bias and fairness is essential for responsible, trustworthy, and legally compliant ML systems.

Attempt to explicitly define outcomes and relevant KPIs for those outcomes. Where that can not happen, it is important to understand why that can not happen. What is happening if we dont have and follow metrics. IE. The Account Opening Process is not effiicient and needs to improve, The Internet Banking Experience is poor, and does not attract customers. How do you monitor this, how can you define this, how can you prove this,  how do you expect this to change and measure that change.

How will the project and efforts be measured where success can not be objectively measured? How will resources be allocated when it remains unclear what benefit or risk exists.

Must be careful at how problem is defined. Is it defined in the context of the already identifed solution, has it been validated and is the problem distinct from the analysis and potential solution, or have we leaked into the process.

How Invested are stakeholders in defining the problem? What is their view of the process/ project, how invested, interested and engaged are they. What are their personal goals and motivation, speed, accuracy, validation of ideology?

Proceed with extreme caution where the problem statement is incomplete, or ill-stated, as this is likely indicative that the problem is not truly understood or at a minimum defined. Where this is the case, the project will be at extreme risk and the likelihood of not meeting expectations, frustration, or material change to purpose, scope or priority is inevitable.

Describe the target outcomes or performance levels that define success. They show what improvement looks like in measurable terms and help guide priorities and actions. This is important because clear targets create alignment, focus efforts, and allow teams to track progress toward meaningful results.

Describes how the process, system, or situation is functioning today. It provides a factual, objective picture of what is happening, without assumptions or solutions. This is important because it ensures everyone has a shared understanding of reality before trying to fix the problem.

Identifies the underlying reasons why the problem exists. Rather than focusing on symptoms, it explores the fundamental drivers using methods such as the “5 Whys” or cause-and-effect analysis. This is important because addressing root causes leads to sustainable improvements, while only treating symptoms often results in recurring issues.

Summarizes what actions, initiatives, or attempts have already been made to address the problem. It explains what was tried, what worked, and what did not. This is important because it prevents repeating past mistakes and helps build on lessons learned.

Quantify the current state of the problem using measurable data such as performance indicators, volumes, timelines, or quality measures. These metrics provide an objective reference point for understanding the scope and impact of the issue. This is important because improvement cannot be measured without a clear starting baseline.

Written down in a clear, accessible format that describes the steps, roles, and expectations. Documentation creates a single source of truth and reduces reliance on memory or informal knowledge. This is important because it ensures consistency, supports training, and allows the process to be sustained even when staff or circumstances change. 

Documented is not sufficient, it must be accessible, available and known. Even when these conditions are met, one must acknowledge that the vast majoirty of people are likely not interested, or willing to read.

Actively shared with all relevant stakeholders so they understand what the process is, why it matters, and how to follow it. Communication includes orientation, reminders, and opportunities for clarification. This is important because even the best-designed process will fail if people are unaware of it or misunderstand their roles, or forget.

Ancillary resources must be available to support implementation and perfection, which is critically important at the outset. This includes  training, coaching, tools, and ongoing guidance, and learning. Another critical compoent of this is monitoring and feedback which is necssary to ensure the process is being applied as intended and working as expected, as it is critical to acknowledge imperfections (or complete failure as appropriate).

Includes defined metrics that track whether the process is being followed and whether it is producing the intended results. Measurement provides objective evidence of performance, progress, and areas needing improvement. This is important because without measurement, it is difficult to know if the process is effective or where adjustments are required.

Also, it is critical to remember that individuals without feedback, may honestly not understand whether they are following a process as designed and intended, depsite their best efforts.

Easy to understand, follow, and execute without unnecessary steps or complexity. Simplicity reduces errors, shortens training time, and makes the process more adaptable to change. The more complex a process is, the less likely it will truly generalize or obtain the support and adoption necessary to perfect and embed.

Communicates expectations, roles, and steps in a way that leaves little room for confusion or interpretation. It ensures that everyone involved understands what to do, when to do it, and how success is defined. Clarity is important because it promotes consistency, accountability, and smooth coordination across teams.

Makes the right actions and outcomes visible through straightforward steps, cues, or built-in checks. It allows people to quickly see whether the process is being followed correctly and whether it is producing the intended results. This is important because visibility helps teams detect issues early and maintain quality.

Mmakes the correct next step intuitive, even for someone new or unfamiliar with the work. It reduces reliance on memory, interpretation, or specialized knowledge to complete tasks correctly. This is important because when the right action is obvious, compliance increases and variation decreases, leading to more reliable outcomes.
Are Roles and Responsbilities explicity stated? and Is it clear who is responsible for what. Are goals SMART (or atleast defined) or at a minimum, is our partcipation understood and documented.
Generate feature importance or explanation outputs. Helps understand what drives model predictions.
Remove features with high missingness or low variance. Reduces noise and improves model stability.
Check for multicollinearity or redundant features. Helps prevent unstable models and improves interpretability.
Validate selected features using model or statistical methods. Ensures the retained features actually contribute to predictive performance.
Avoid ambigious features. Is a Banana ripe, who says so?
Careful when something is truly random generated, Atmospheric Change, Earthquakes, Stocks. Very difficult, if not impossible to predict.

How robust is your model to change and what is it actually predict. 
MNIST performance when tilting Images, of adding noise.

Are Goals Documented. Are the Smart.
If not, what does this imply and how do we proceed forward while mitigating risk.

Describes what will be accomplished and what success will look like. It answers the questions: What will I do? Who is involved? What area am I focusing on? The more precise the goal, the easier it is to plan actions and stay focused.

Includes a clear way to track progress or determine success. This may involve numbers, percentages, milestones, deliverables, or observable outcomes. Measurement ensures accountability and helps you know when the goal has been achieved.

Realistic given available time, resources, skills, and competing priorities. It should stretch performance but still be possible to accomplish with focused effort. Setting achievable goals helps maintain motivation and builds confidence through success.

Aligns with broader priorities, such as team objectives, organizational strategy, or personal development plans. It should contribute meaningful value rather than being an isolated or low-impact task. Relevance ensures time and energy are spent on what matters most.

Includes a clear deadline or timeframe for completion. This creates urgency, supports planning, and prevents goals from being postponed indefinitely. Defined timelines also make it easier to monitor progress and adjust actions if needed.
Define a clear search space for key hyperparameters. Ensures tuning focuses on meaningful configurations.
Use cross-validation or a validation set for tuning. Prevents overfitting to the training data.
Record best parameters and associated performance. Allows reproducibility and comparison across experiments.

Define Parameters you will tune and approach to tuning before you commence tuning. Do not simply tune model to optimal parameters without considering what you are actually doing, and its ability to generalize.

Define what the objective of the model work is, state what is being measured and why. Document all models which will be considered, including why they are appropriate and where models are excluded, insure rationale available. Compare multiple model types using the same validation approach. Ensures a fair comparison and better-informed model choice.

Create Simplified Baseline Model, use this are reference. Ensure that this is communicated to Stakeholders, so they understand both the benchmark and expectation, to determine relevance. Should align with Goals.
Consider interpretability, performance, and computational cost. Balances practical constraints with predictive accuracy.
Is split between Training, Testing and Validation appropriate, fair and responsable. Validate and document.
Verify model converges and loss decreases during training. Confirms the model is learning meaningful patterns.
Log model parameters, features, training configuration and results. Supports reproducibility and troubleshooting.
Ensure that final selection is documented and agreed by apporpiate stakeholders, who have been part of entire development journey, understand and are aware.
Use cross-validation or a structured validation approach. Provides a more reliable estimate of model performance.
Ensure no data leakage between training and validation sets. Prevents overly optimistic performance estimates.
Confirm performance stability across folds or time splits. Indicates the model is robust and generalizable.

Models will cheat and can solve problems which appear to be optimal, but they might not be solving what you expect or require, they might be finding patterns in the data which you do not see. An Example of this would a classification model with Wolves and Dogs,  many wolf photos happened to be taken in snowy environments, while dog photos were often taken indoors or on grass. The model learned to detect snow, not animals.
Any data set can be optimized, even when there is NO relation it will generalize. Remember the goal, ability to generalize, not simply predict training.
What consessions have we made due to a lack of data availability, and how are those going to undermine the work we plan on doing.
Who is the Data Steward, are they involved, and operationally do we have integrity, consistency and availability to include?
Review Semantic and Functional Definitions, ensuring there is sufficient and appropriate coverage. Testing and decisioning to occur during Feature Selection.

What ratios or proportions could better represent behavior than raw values? Many real-world patterns depend on relative size (e.g., debt-to-income, usage-to-capacity), so ratios often reveal signal that absolute values hide.

What combinations or interactions might reflect how factors work together? Some outcomes are driven by the interaction between variables (e.g., high balance and high transaction frequency), so combining features can expose relationships a model might miss.

What time-based changes or aggregates could capture trends or stability? Differences, growth rates, or rolling averages often reflect momentum or consistency, which are strong predictors of future behavior.
Use metrics appropriate to the problem type and business goal. Ensures the model is evaluated in a way that reflects real-world impact.
Evaluate performance on a hold-out test set. Provides an unbiased estimate of generalization performance.
Check for overfitting by comparing training and test results. Identifies models that may not perform well in production.
Utilize feature importance metrics to visualize and explain.
This should be a formal step as engagement along the way has predicted on this as a core tenant and principle. If people seem shocked, embed stronger components earlier in process.
Document model behavior and major drivers. Supports stakeholder understanding and auditability.
Package the model with all required preprocessing steps. Ensures predictions in production match training conditions.
Test the model in a staging or test environment. Utilize Dedicated Environment. Reduces risk of failures in production.
Create a versioned and reproducible deployment artifact. Supports rollback, auditing, and maintenance.
Track model performance metrics over time. Detects degradation or drift after deployment.
Monitor input data distributions for drift. Identifies changes in data that could affect predictions.
Define triggers for retraining or model review. Ensures timely corrective action when performance declines.
Evaluate model performance across key demographic or operational groups. Identifies potential unfair or unequal outcomes.
Review sensitive features and proxy variables. Prevents unintended discrimination.
Document fairness checks and mitigation steps. Supports transparency, accountability, and compliance.
Define strategies around Imputation, Deletion, Standardization.
Model Pipleine, including training, testing and validation strategies.
